title: How to Cook an Eggplant Omelette

steps.headline: Place the Asian eggplants, whole, on a baking sheet and stab the eggplants with a fork a few times to prevent the skin from popping in the oven.
steps.description: Bake for 30-35 minutes or until the eggplants are soft. If the eggplants are still too firm and resistant, bake for another 5-10 minutes. The eggplants will need to be soft enough to mash later.

steps.headline: Remove the eggplants from the oven and allow them to cool until they are no longer too hot to touch.
Peel off the eggplants' skins, but make sure the stem stays attached.
steps.description: One simple method is to use a knife to shallowly cut the skin around the top and peel it off in long strips with a fork and your fingers. The skin should come off easily. Be careful not to burn yourself if the eggplants are still hot.

steps.headline: Mash the eggplants flat with a fork.
steps.description: If the flesh is still resistant and rubbery, then the eggplants were not baked long enough.

steps.headline: Dash the eggplants with salt and pepper on both sides.
Dip the eggplants in the beaten egg mixture.
steps.description: Use the stem as a handle to dip the eggplants. Make sure that the vegetables are liberally coated with egg.

steps.headline: Fry the vegetables in a pan with vegetable oil, pouring the remaining portion of the egg mixture over the eggplants.

text: Preheat your oven to 375 °F (191 °C).  Place the Asian eggplants, whole, on a baking sheet and stab the eggplants with a fork a few times to prevent the skin from popping in the oven. Bake for 30-35 minutes or until the eggplants are soft. If the eggplants are still too firm and resistant, bake for another 5-10 minutes. The eggplants will need to be soft enough to mash later. Remove the eggplants from the oven and allow them to cool until they are no longer too hot to touch.  Peel off the eggplants' skins, but make sure the stem stays attached. One simple method is to use a knife to shallowly cut the skin around the top and peel it off in long strips with a fork and your fingers. The skin should come off easily. Be careful not to burn yourself if the eggplants are still hot. Mash the eggplants flat with a fork. If the flesh is still resistant and rubbery, then the eggplants were not baked long enough. Dash the eggplants with salt and pepper on both sides.  Beat two eggs.  Dip the eggplants in the beaten egg mixture. Use the stem as a handle to dip the eggplants. Make sure that the vegetables are liberally coated with egg. Fry the vegetables in a pan with vegetable oil, pouring the remaining portion of the egg mixture over the eggplants.  Serve hot and enjoy!
